Hello, PSAS Friends, This chapter will be focused on variables only. You will be introduced to a various variables that are most commonly used in your research work and in social life. Since the concepts of these variable are defined and discussed in the slides, for the notes section, however, I will give you some examples to help you understand better the concepts so that you can comprehend the variables in depth. In addition, these notes will pinpoint independent, dependent, continuous, discrete, nominal/categorical variables.

A quote from an internet source for defining a variable:

You won't be able to do very much in research unless you know how to talk about variables. A variable is any entity that can take on different values. OK, so what does that mean? Anything that can vary can be considered a variable. For instance, age can be considered a variable because age can take different values for different people or for the same person at different times. Similarly, country can be considered a variable because a person's country can be assigned a value.

http://www.socialresearchmethods.net/kb/variable.php

The distinction between the above categories of demographic, economic, social, or psychological variables varies, depending on how the research define them. Therefore when you use these terms, you should also give them a definition supported by literature.
Constant is not our focus in doing social science research but is necessary to know the concept of it.

Here is an example of definition:
An independent variable, sometimes called an experimental or predictor variable, is a variable that is being manipulated in an experiment in order to observe the effect on a dependent variable, sometimes called an outcome variable.

Another definition from http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/discrete_variable
A variable that takes values from a finite or countable set, such as the number of legs of an animal.
